html:
Diagram of the possible mechanism for CRISPR.[citation needed]

CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) are direct repeats found in approximately 40% of bacteria and 90% of archaea. CRISPR functions as a prokaryotic immune system, in that it infers resistance to exogenous genetic elements, such as plasmids or bacterial phage DNA. The CRISPR system provides a form of acquired immunity against exogenous DNA by integrating the foreign DNA into its genome. The integrated DNA is then used to remove foreign elements with the associated genes in a mechanism similar to RNAi in eukaryotic organisms.

Contents

  • 1 CRISPR Mechanism
  • 2 CRISPR Spacers and Repeats
  • 3 References
  • 4 External links

CRISPR Mechanism

Exogenous DNA is processed by specific CRISPR associated genes (CAS), which cleave the DNA into small elements (of ~30bp in length), which are then inserted into the CRISPR leader. These CRISPR genes are constitutively expressed and the palindromic sections of the expressed RNA form hairpin loops. The hairpin loops are processed by another set of CAS genes, which results in the remaining spacers, the crRNAs, which are then guided by CAS genes to complementary genetic material to inhibit translation.

CRISPR Spacers and Repeats

CRISPR repeats range in size from 24 to 48 base pairs. They usually show some dyad symmetry but are not truly palindromic. The repeats are separated by spacers of similar length. The Spacers are usually unique in a genome and most spacer sequences match sequences in phage genomes. These spacers can be derived from phage and subsequently help protect the cell from infection. Consequently, an active CRISPR repeat array evolves rapidly do to incoming phage infections. Different strains of the same species of bacterium often can be differentiated according to differences in the spacers in their CRISPR arrays, a technique called spoligotyping[1].

Sets of genes have been described recently that are found only in genomes that contain CRISPR repeats, and almost always near the repeats themselves. Such CRISPR-associated genes are called cas genes. More than forty different Cas protein families have been described. The most important of these is Cas1, which is present in almost every CRISPR/Cas system. Particular combinations of cas genes are found together regularly, along with characteristic subclasses of CRISPR repeat and corresponding subfamilies of the Cas1 family. These combinations appear to represent distinct CRISPR/Cas subtypes; several different subtypes may occur in a single genome. The sporadic distribution of each CRISPR/cas subtype suggests that these elements undergo numerous horizontal gene transfer events during microbial evolution. In the bacteria E. coli the CasA-E proteins form a functional complex, Cascade, that process CRISPR RNA transcripts into spacer-repeat units that are retained by Cascade. CRISPR-based phage inactivation in E. coli requires Cascade and Cas3, but not Cas1 and Cas2.
